prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
In order to detect small-scale structures and their kinematics, we will use the most extended array configuration in Band 7 with CO (3–2) and HCO+ (4-3) lines and 344 and 355.5 GHz continuum in Dual Polarization mode. For the two lines, 468.750 MHz in bandwidth and ~ 0.2 km s-1 in velocity resolution, which can well resolve Keplerian motion within 100 AU, are selected. For continuum observation, 2GHz was selected for bandwidth to maximize the sensitivity. The requested sensitivity is 4 mJy for the CO (3–2) line, which will need the total observing time of 3.47 hours (1.53 hours on source), estimated by the ALMA Sensitivity Calculator.
(1) Observing frequency The band selection is based not only on the scientific merit but also on feasibility. We selected CO (3–2), rather than CO (2–1), as a primary probe for the gaseous disk since the higher angular resolution is important to spatially resolve the small-scale structures. The angular resolution of CO (3–2) line is approximately 0.12”, while CO (2–1) line achieves 0.18” in angular resolution. The outer radius of the J1604 cavity is 0.4”, which means that we will be able to observe the cavity with several separate beams. Although higher spatial resolution can be attained by CO (6–5) in Band 9, the deep absorption in CO (6–5) was seen in similar object by APEX. As a result, optically thick CO (3–2) whose maximum angular scale of 0.12” achievable by the most extended configuration at Band 7 is suitable for investigating the cavity. We decided to use HCO+ (4-3) line, which is simultaneously observed, for detecting the gas component in the cavity. It is less contaminated by the background gas than the other lines with comparable strength such as 13CO (3-2), because the background gas is not dense enough to excite the rotational levels of HCO+. Therefore, it is useful for tracing gas when a lot of gas exist around the cavity (see Casassus et al. 2013). Continuum observation at band 7 can achieve to the comparable spatial resolution of Subaru image and make it possible to directly compare between mm-sized and μm-sized dust distribution. Therefore, CO (3–2) and 344 GHz continuum are set to be in Lower Side Band and HCO+ (4-3) and 355.5 GHz continuum are set to be in the Upper Side Band.
(2) Velocity Resolution and Sensitivity Lower velocity resolution gives higher sensitivity that is important to detect the depleted gas in the cavity. However, lower resolution is not necessarily a good choice if there is a steep velocity gradient within the beam and the emission is not uniformly distributed over the velocity range. In addition, to explore the gas kinematics and its deviation from a Keplerian orbit, higher velocity resolution is essential. As a result, the velocity resolution is chosen in such a way that the Keplerian velocity is well resolved and the thermal width (~ 1/10 of Keplerian velocity) at inner radii can be marginally resolved. To satisfy the conditions above, velocity resolution of ~ 0.2 km s-1 for CO (3-2) and HCO+ (4-3) line observations is selected so that the Keplerian motion within 100 AU is well resolved.
Our observational setup also allows us to observe the dust continuum with the 1σsensitivity down to approximately 0.04 mJy/beam when 4 GHz bandwidth is used. This means that it is capable of detecting a typical disk around low-mass star with tremendously high signal-to-noise ratio, for example GM Aur has 65 mJy per SMA beam of 0.32” x 0.27” (Andrews et al. 2011). As a result, the expected asymmetric structure can be safely detected if it exists.

In order to detect small-scale structures and their kinematics, we will use the most extended array configuration in Band 7 with CO (3–2) and HCO+ (4-3) lines and 344 and 355.5 GHz continuum in Dual Polarization mode. For the two lines, 468.750 MHz in bandwidth and ~ 0.2 km s-1 in velocity resolution, which can well resolve Keplerian motion within 100 AU, are selected. For continuum observation, 2GHz was selected for bandwidth to maximize the sensitivity. The requested sensitivity is 3.5 mJy for the CO (3–2) line, which will need the total observing time of 4.88 hours (2.00 hours on source), estimated by the ALMA Sensitivity Calculator.
(1) Observing frequency The band selection is based not only on the scientific merit but also on feasibility. We selected CO (3–2), rather than CO (2–1), as a primary probe for the gaseous disk since the higher angular resolution is important to spatially resolve the small-scale structures. The angular resolution of CO (3–2) line is approximately 0.12”, while CO (2–1) line achieves 0.18” in angular resolution. The outer radius of the UX Tau A cavity is 0.18”, which means that we will be able to spatially resolve the cavity. Although higher spatial resolution can be attained by CO (6–5) in Band 9, the deep absorption in CO (6–5) was seen in similar object by APEX. As a result, optically thick CO (3–2) whose maximum angular scale of 0.12” achievable by the most extended configuration at Band 7 is suitable for investigating the cavity. We decided to use HCO+ (4-3) line, which is simultaneously observed, for detecting the gas component in the cavity. It is less contaminated by the background gas than the other lines with comparable strength such as 13CO (3-2), because the background gas is not dense enough to excite the rotational levels of HCO+. Therefore, it is useful for tracing gas when a lot of gas exist around the cavity (see Casassus et al. 2013). Continuum observation at band 7 can achieve to the comparable spatial resolution of Subaru image and make it possible to directly compare between mm-sized and μm-sized dust distribution. Therefore, CO (3–2) and 344 GHz continuum are set to be in Lower Side Band and HCO+ (4-3) and 355.5 GHz continuum are set to be in the Upper Side Band.
(2) Velocity Resolution and Sensitivity Lower velocity resolution gives higher sensitivity that is important to detect the depleted gas in the cavity. However, lower resolution is not necessarily a good choice if there is a steep velocity gradient within the beam and the emission is not uniformly distributed over the velocity range. In addition, to explore the gas kinematics and its deviation from a Keplerian orbit, higher velocity resolution is essential. As a result, the velocity resolution is chosen in such a way that the Keplerian velocity is well resolved and the thermal width (~ 1/10 of Keplerian velocity) at inner radii can be marginally resolved. To satisfy the conditions above, velocity resolution of ~ 0.2 km s-1 for CO (3-2) and HCO+ (4-3) line observations is selected so that the Keplerian motion within 100 AU is well resolved.
Our observational setup also allows us to observe the dust continuum with the 1σsensitivity down to approximately 0.03 mJy/beam when 4 GHz bandwidth is used. This means that it is capable of detecting a typical disk around low-mass star with tremendously high signal-to-noise ratio, for example UX Tau A has 38 mJy per SMA beam of 0.31” x 0.28” (Andrews et al. 2011). As a result, the expected asymmetric structure can be safely detected if it exists.

In order to detect small-scale structures and their kinematics, we will use the most extended array configuration in Band 7 with CO (3–2) and HCO+ (4-3) lines and 344 and 355.5 GHz continuum in Dual Polarization mode. For the two lines, 468.750 MHz in bandwidth and ~ 0.2 km s-1 in velocity resolution, which can well resolve Keplerian motion within 100 AU, are selected. For continuum observation, 2GHz was selected for bandwidth to maximize the sensitivity. The requested sensitivity is 4 mJy for the CO (3–2) line, which will need the total observing time of 3.67 hours (1.60 hours on source), estimated by the ALMA Sensitivity Calculator.
(1) Observing frequency The band selection is based not only on the scientific merit but also on feasibility. We selected CO (3–2), rather than CO (2–1), as a primary probe for the gaseous disk since the higher angular resolution is important to spatially resolve the small-scale structures. The angular resolution of CO (3–2) line is approximately 0.12”, while CO (2–1) line achieves 0.18” in angular resolution. Although higher spatial resolution can be attained by CO (6–5) in Band 9, the deep absorption in CO (6–5) was seen in similar object by APEX. As a result, optically thick CO (3–2) whose maximum angular scale of 0.12” achievable by the most extended configuration at Band 7 is suitable for investigating the cavity. However, lower resolution is not necessarily a good choice if there is a steep velocity gradient within the beam and the emission is not uniformly distributed over the velocity range. Our observational setup also allows us to observe the dust continuum with the 1σsensitivity down to approximately 0.04 mJy/beam when 4 GHz bandwidth is used. This means that it is capable of detecting a typical disk around low-mass star with tremendously high signal-to-noise ratio, for example GM Aur has 65 mJy per SMA beam of 0.32” x 0.27” (Andrews et al. 2011). As a result, the expected asymmetric structure can be safely detected if it exists.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: It has become evident that protoplanetary disks have complex structures and capable of examining the inner region (a few × 10 AU) of protoplanetary disks. The SEEDS project and other observations have revealed that 2MASS J16042165-2130284, UX Tau A, and PDS 70 have a large cavity and, in conjunction with SED, they have structure and kinematics in it, such as clumpy structure inside a cavity, possibly material supply of planets, and a high mass accretion rate suggesting that mass accretion from outer disk to the inner region of the disk may occurs. We want to observe the cavity of protoplanetary disks, as well as the inner edge structure of the outer disk, with comparable spatial resolution with our Subaru image. We selected dust continuum, CO (J=3–2), and HCO+ (J=4–3) for investigating dust and gas density structures and their kinematics. If emission inside of a cavity is detected (suggested by Takami et al. 2013 submitted), structure and physical property in the cavity, which is probably influenced by planet, the link between inner and outer region of disks, and the process of material supply to early stage of proto-planet will become clear.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: ALMA Project Office, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Extra-Solar Planet Detection Project Office, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
